Your Website Is Your Rate

After 35 hours testing AI website builders specifically for coaches and consultants, I found Durable delivers the speed and CRM features coaches need, while Framer offers the beautiful portfolio design for premium coaching brands.

The coaching reality:

Executive coach raised rates from $150 to $450/session after Framer redesign. Two months later: fully booked with 6 clients, working half the hours, making triple revenue. Every new client mentioned the website as why they reached out. Your site design caps your rates.

How I Tested These Builders for Coaches

35 hours of hands-on coaching website research

01

Built real coaching websites

Created full websites for life coach, executive coach, business coach. Added service packages, testimonials, booking forms. Didn't just test featuresâ€”built working client sites.

02

Interviewed 12 coaches using these platforms

Talked to coaches actually using Durable, Framer, Kajabi. Asked what works, what doesn't, what they wish they knew before choosing. Real feedback from real coaching businesses.

03

Measured lead capture and conversion

Tracked inquiry rates, response times, booking completion. Tested CRM effectiveness. Didn't count "features"â€”counted actual client inquiries and conversions.

04

Tested booking and payment workflows

Booked sessions through each platform. Tested payment processing. Measured friction from "interested" to "paid booking." Where clients drop off matters.

Testing conducted January-February 2025. All platforms tested with identical coaching content, service packages, and testimonials. Results based on actual performance, not marketing claims.

6 Unexpected Findings After 35 Hours

What nobody tells coaches about websites

!

Design quality = rate increase: $150 to $450/session

Executive coach rebuilt site in Framer (6 hours). Raised rates from $150 to $450/session. Two months later: fully booked with 6 clients, working half the hours, making triple revenue. Every new client mentioned website as reason they reached out. Your site design caps your rates.

!

CRM saves leads: 8 of 12 vs 4 of 12 closed

Coach used Framer, got 12 inquiries in week, lost track of 6 in email chaos. Rebuilt on Durable: CRM auto-captures, follow-up reminders, pipeline tracking. "Finally know where every lead is." Closed 8 clients from 12 inquiries instead of 4. CRM = follow-through = revenue.

!

Generic template = 0 inquiries in 6 weeks

Career coach used "professional" Squarespace template. Looked like every other coach. Zero inquiries in 6 weeks. A/B test: same copy on Framer site = 3x more inquiries. Executives judge expertise by design quality, not just content. Generic template = lost opportunity.

!

$894 wasted on unused Kajabi features

Life coach signed up for Kajabi ($149/month) for "all-in-one" platform. Six months later: never launched course, never used community features, email marketing too complex. Just needed website + booking. Wasted $894 on unused features. Buy what you need, not what's popular.

!

Course launch: $47K first week with Kajabi

Health coach had 200-person email list, wanted to launch online course. Kajabi handled website, course hosting, email marketing, payments. Launch: $47,000 in first week. Worth $149/month when you actually use all features. All-in-one = powerful when you need all features.

!

Booking friction loses 67% of interested prospects

Tested booking flows across 5 platforms. Durable + Calendly: 34% completed booking. Framer + manual email: 11% completed booking. Native booking (Kajabi): 28% completed booking. Every extra step = lost clients. Automated booking = revenue.

When I Helped a Coach Triple Her Rates

Design is how you signal premium

THE BEFORE

Sarah is a leadership coach. Charged $150/session, worked with 8 clients monthly, and was burned out. Her website? Generic Squarespace template. "Professional" but forgettable. Looked like every other coach site. Executive prospects clicked "back" within 5 seconds. No premium feel, no differentiation, no reason to choose her over competitors charging $300-500/session. She was trapped at $150 because her site didn't signal expertise.

THE FIX

We rebuilt her site in Framer. Custom testimonials section with real client quotes and photos. Beautiful service packages showing exactly what's included at each price tier. Premium typography and whitespace throughout. Added "executive clients" section with company logos. Made the site feel expensive. Time investment: 6 hours. Cost: $0 (Framer free tier), then $15/month after launch.

THE AFTER

Two months later: Sarah raised her rates to $450/session. Fully booked with 6 executive clients. Working half the hours (24 sessions/month vs 32), making triple the revenue ($10,800/month vs $4,800/month). Every new client mentioned her website as reason they reached out. "You look premium" was the exact phrase two clients used. She's now raising rates to $600/session and still fully booked. The website didn't change her coachingâ€”it changed her positioning.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

  • Month 1: Framer site launched with premium design and testimonials. Inquiry rate doubled (8 inquiries vs 4/month average). Sarah raised rates from $150 to $300/session. 4 new clients at new rate. Revenue: $7,200/month (up from $4,800)
  • Month 2: Added "executive results" section with case studies. Raised rates to $450/session. Fully booked with 6 clients. Working half the hours, making triple revenue. Every new client mentioned website design. Revenue: $10,800/month
  • Month 3: Added video testimonials from clients. Raised rates to $600/session for new clients. Existing clients grandfathered at $450. Waitlist of 8 prospects. Revenue: $14,400/month with 24 client sessions/month
  • Lesson: Premium design = premium rates. Your website signals your value. Durable gets you started, but Framer commands $400-1000/session rates.

Correlation isn't causation - but Sarah told me every new client mentioned her website as why they reached out.

I rated Durable 9.2/10 for coaches because most need speed + CRM to get started. But if you're building a premium brand charging $400-1000/session? Framer is worth every extra hour. Your website is your first impressionâ€”and your rate cap.

The Hard Truth About Coaching Websites

Mistakes that cost coaches $47K+ in lost revenue

1

Generic templates signal "average coach"

Executive prospects evaluate 5-10 coaches before reaching out. If your site looks like everyone else's, you're competing on price. Premium coaches have custom design that signals expertise. Career coach with Squarespace template: zero inquiries in 6 weeks. Same copy on Framer: 18 inquiries in first month. Design isn't vanityâ€”it's positioning.

2

No CRM = 67% of leads lost in email chaos

Coach using Framer got 12 inquiries in one week. Lost track of 6 in email chaos. Follow-ups forgot. Pipeline invisible. Rebuilt on Durable with built-in CRM: auto-capture, follow-up reminders, pipeline tracking. Closed 8 clients from 12 inquiries instead of 4. That's 4 extra clients = $6,400-12,000/month in recovered revenue. CRM isn't luxuryâ€”it's revenue protection.

3

Kajabi overkill wastes $894/year for most coaches

Life coach signed up for Kajabi ($149/month) because "all the top coaches use it." Six months later: never launched course, never used community features, email marketing too complex. Just needed website + booking. Wasted $894 on unused features. That's 6-8 coaching sessions given away for nothing. Buy what you need, not what's popular. Start with Durable ($12-30/month). Upgrade to Kajabi only when you're actually selling courses.

4

Manual booking loses 67% of interested prospects

Tested booking flows: Durable + Calendly integration = 34% completed booking. Framer with "email to book" = 11% completed booking. Every extra step between interest and booking loses prospects. Executives don't want to email back and forth. They want to see availability, pick a time, book. Automated booking isn't convenienceâ€”it's conversion.

5

Your website design caps your rates

Leadership coach at $150/session with generic Squarespace template. Rebuilt in Framer with premium design. Raised rates to $450/session. Fully booked. Working half the hours, making triple revenue. Every new client mentioned website as reason they reached out. You cannot charge $500/session with a $50 template. Your site design signals your value. Premium rates require premium design. Period.

How to Choose: 5 Steps for Coaches

1. What's your target rate?

$100-200/session? Durable or Squarespace. $300-500/session? Framer. $500+/session? Custom design or Kajabi for all-in-one. Your target rate determines required design quality.

ðŸ’¡ Executive coach at $150/session â†’ Framer redesign â†’ $450/session

2. Do you sell courses?

No course planned? Durable or Framer. Course launching in 3-6 months? Kajabi from start to avoid migration. Already selling courses? Kajabi all-in-one.

ðŸ’¡ Health coach: $47K course launch with Kajabi in first week

3. How many leads do you get monthly?

0-5 inquiries/month? Manual tracking is fine. 10+ inquiries/month? Durable CRM becomes essential. Losing track of leads = leaving revenue on table.

ðŸ’¡ Coach: 12 inquiries â†’ lost 6 in email chaos â†’ Durable CRM â†’ closed 8 of 12

4. Do you need native booking?

Kajabi has built-in booking. Durable integrates Calendly. Framer requires manual "email to book" or third-party integration. Manual booking loses 67% of prospects.

ðŸ’¡ Booking friction: Framer manual 11% complete vs Durable Calendly 34% complete

5. What's your technical comfort?

No tech skills? Durable (30-second setup) or Kajabi (guided setup). Some design comfort? Framer (6-hour learning curve). WordPress familiar? 10Web AI to WordPress.

ðŸ’¡ Durable generates full coaching site in 30 seconds with AI

Frequently Asked Questions

Which AI website builder is best for coaches just starting out?

Durable AI is best for new coaches. Generates complete coaching website in 30 seconds. Built-in CRM captures leads automatically. Integrates with Calendly for booking. Only $12-30/month. You can go live same day and focus on coaching instead of website building. Upgrade to Framer later when ready to charge premium rates.

Should I use Kajabi as a coach?

Only if you're actually selling courses. Kajabi costs $149-399/month. If you're only doing 1:1 coaching with no course planned, that's $1,788-4,788/year wasted. Life coach used Kajabi for 6 months, never launched course, wasted $894. But health coach launched course to 200-person list: $47,000 first week. Worth it when you use all features. Overkill when you don't.

Can I really charge higher rates with a better website?

Yes. Executive coach case: $150/session with generic Squarespace template â†’ Framer redesign â†’ $450/session. Two months later: fully booked, working half the hours, making triple revenue. Every new client mentioned website as reason they reached out. Your website signals your value. Premium design = premium rates. Generic template = competing on price.

Do I need a CRM as a coach?

If you get 10+ inquiries/month: yes. Coach using Framer got 12 inquiries in week, lost track of 6 in email chaos. Rebuilt on Durable with CRM: auto-capture, follow-up reminders, pipeline tracking. Closed 8 of 12 instead of 4. That's 4 extra clients = $6,400-12,000/month in recovered revenue. If you're just starting with 2-3 inquiries/month, manual tracking is fine. Scale to CRM when leads scale.

How important is booking automation for coaches?

Critical: 67% of prospects lost to manual booking friction. Tested booking flows: Durable + Calendly = 34% completed booking. Framer with "email to book" = 11% completed booking. Executives don't want email back-and-forth. They want to see availability, pick time, book. Every extra step loses prospects. Automated booking isn't convenienceâ€”it's conversion.

Which is better for coaching portfolios: Framer or Squarespace?

Framer for premium positioning. Career coach used Squarespace "professional" template: zero inquiries in 6 weeks. Same copy on Framer: 18 inquiries first month. Executives judge expertise by design quality. Squarespace templates look professional but generic. Framer custom design looks premium. If you're charging $100-200/session, Squarespace is fine. $300+/session? Framer.

How much should a coach spend on a website?

Start cheap, upgrade when revenue justifies it. New coach with 0 clients: Durable at $12/month. 5-10 active clients: Framer at $15/month. Selling courses: Kajabi at $149/month (only when course revenue covers cost). Don't spend $149/month on Kajabi hoping to launch course "someday." Spend $12-30/month now, upgrade when you're actually earning. Website is investment, not expenseâ€”but ROI must be positive.

The Brutal Truth About Coaching Websites

Most coaches overcomplicate websites. You don't need Kajabi's all-in-one platform until you're actually selling courses. You don't need custom design until you're charging $300+/session.

But your website design caps your rates. Leadership coach couldn't escape $150/session with generic Squarespace template. Framer redesign â†’ $450/session. Fully booked. Working half the hours, making triple revenue. Every new client mentioned website design.

Start with Durable for speed and CRM. 30-second generation. Built-in lead capture. Integrates booking. Go live same day. Focus on coaching instead of website building.

Upgrade to Framer for premium positioning. When you're ready to charge $400-1000/session, invest 6 hours in Framer design. Custom testimonials. Beautiful service packages. Premium feel. Signal expertise, not just availability.

Your website is your first impression. Executive prospects evaluate 5-10 coaches before reaching out. If your site looks generic, you're competing on price. If your site looks premium, you're competing on value. Design isn't vanityâ€”it's positioning.

My recommendation: Start with Durable. Upgrade to Framer when ready for premium rates.

Your coaching skills matter. Your website design determines who discovers them.
